person.note:
Categories:
People -- Veterans
People -- Widowers
People -- Men

note.p: Hezekiah William Foote was a Confederate officer and politician in Mississippi.

Born on December 17, 1813, in Chester County, South Carolina, Foote moved to Macon, Mississippi, in his youth. He studied law and became a practicing attorney, but also worked as a farmer raising cattle, a newspaper editor, a Chancery Clerk, and a district judge. He was a member of the Whig Party and unsuccessfully ran for the Mississippi House of Representatives in the mid-1850s.

When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Foote volunteered for military service. He was made a captain in the First Mississippi Cavalry Battalion, and later was promoted to colonel within the Mississippi state militia. Foote saw action at Belmont and Shiloh.

After the war, Foote again pursued political office. He was elected to the Mississippi House of Representatives and the Mississippi Senate. Through his various business pursuits (which included serving as president of the Farmers and Merchants Bank in Macon, Mississippi), as well as property he received through marriage, Foote became extremely wealthy. He owned at least four plantations, and helped found Vanderbilt University in Tennessee.

Foote died on January 29, 1899. He had been married four times, first to Lucinda Davis, who passed away in 1856. He then married Margy G. Foote (a cousin), who died in 1859. Foote then married Sybilla Antoinette Messinger, and was last married to Eleanor W. Curtiss. He had at least nine children. Foote is buried at Odd Fellows Cemetery in Macon, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)
Hezekiah William Foote belonged to the following social groups:

person.note:
Categories:
People -- Charged with Criminal Activity
People -- Men

note.p: D. C. Kearns was a Republican official in Mississippi during Reconstruction.

Born around 1840 in Virginia, Kearns lived in Ohio at the start of the Civil War and then moved to Mississippi in 1867. He became a clerk in the chancery court of Jefferson County, and involved in Republican party politics over the next several years. In 1869, he served as the governor's private secretary. Kearns’ time as a public official in the Reconstruction government soon proved controversial. Among the most serious incidents involved accusations of him embezzling thousands of dollars while serving as a deputy revenue collector in Mississippi in 1871. Charged and convicted of the crime, he was fined $6,000 and sentenced to twelve months in prison. However, Kearns received a presidential pardon, overturning both the jail time and the fine.

Kearns continued to be involved in Republican politics, serving various public and political positions through the 1870s. He testified before the U.S. Senate in 1876 about the disenfranchisement of Black voters in Mississippi. However, when Reconstruction ended in 1877, critics accused him of trying to switch parties and ingratiate himself with Mississippi Democrats. He passed away from an unspecified cause in 1878.

(1870 U.S. Census for Fayette, Jefferson County, Mississippi; Testimony as to Denial of Elective Franchise in Mississippi at the Elections of 1875 and 1876, 694; “Simon M. Preston,” Report No. 674, House of Representatives, 43rd Congress, 1st Session; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, October 12, 1871, February 14, 1877, and November 13, 1878; Daily Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, October 3, 1875)
D. C. Kearns belonged to the following social groups:

person.persName: Campbell, J. A. P. (Josiah Abigail Patterson), 1830-1917
person.note:
Categories:
People -- Veterans
People -- Widowers
People -- Men

note.p: Josiah Abigail Patterson Campbell was a politician, attorney, and chief justice of the Mississippi Supreme Court during the nineteenth century.

Born on March 2, 1830, in Lancaster District, South Carolina, Campbell attended Davidson College in North Carolina and then moved to Madison County, Mississippi, around 1845. Highly intelligent, he studied law and became the youngest practicing attorney in Mississippi at the age of 17, in 1847. His legal practice thrived and he entered politics in 1851. Campbell won election to the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1851 and 1859, and served as the speaker of the house in 1859 and 1860.

When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Campbell served in the Provisional Confederate Congress and was one of the original signers of the Confederate Constitution. He then volunteered for military service, was commissioned a lieutenant colonel in the Fortieth Mississippi Infantry Regiment, and was wounded in the Second Battle of Corinth.

Following the Civil War, Campbell was elected a circuit judge, but was ejected from office by federal authorities in 1868 after refusing to swear allegiance to the United States. He strongly opposed Republican Reconstruction, and played an active part in the Mississippi Plan, which involved the use of political pressure and violence against Republicans and African Americans to reestablish conservative white, Democratic control of Mississippi. He also participated in framing the Mississippi legal codes of 1871 and 1880.

Campbell received an appointment to the Mississippi Supreme Court in 1876 and served until 1894. He was chief justice during his last three years on the court. Campbell also participated in the drafting of Mississippi’s 1890 constitution, which dismantled some of Reconstruction policies and strengthened white supremacy in the state. After leaving the Mississippi Supreme Court, Campbell returned to private law practice. He died on January 10, 1917. He was married to Eugenia Nash and had at least four children. He is buried in Greenwood Cemetery in Jackson, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)
Josiah Abigail Patterson Campbell belonged to the following social groups:
Solomon "Saul" Saladin Calhoun belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)
Located in Madison County, Canton was incorporated in 1836 and serves as the county seat. (Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries; Rowland, Mississippi, 350)

gloss.p: "The crime of taking something that does not belong to you, but not in a way that involves force or the threat of force." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of illegally taking something that belongs to someone else." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The act of using legal authority to catch and take someone to a place where the person may be accused of a crime." (CD)
"The act of putting someone in prison or the condition of being kept in prison." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"If someone who has committed a crime is pardoned, that person is officially forgiven and their punishment is stopped." (Cambridge Dictionary)"An act of mercy by a person in authority toward someone who has committed a crime, esp. by reducing a punishment." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An occasion when someone is allowed to leave prison, etc." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"In law, a sentence is the punishment for a crime ordered by a trial court after conviction in a criminal procedure, normally at the conclusion of a trial. A sentence may consist of imprisonment, a fine, or other sanctions." (Wikipedia)
"The top legal officer in some countries, whose job is to provide legal advice to the government and to represent the government." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person in charge of an auction who calls out the prices that people offer." (Cambridge Dictionary)

“Someone who works in an office, writing letters, making phone calls, and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization.” (Cambridge Dictionary) CWRGM includes people who perform administrative assistance under this tag, but we do not include government positions that incorporate the word secretary, such as Secretary of State, under this subject tag.
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A building where criminals are forced to live as a punishment." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

"Mississippi State Penitentiary, also known as Parchman Farm, is a maximum-security prison farm located in unincorporated Sunflower County, Mississippi, in the Mississippi Delta region. Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

div.p:
Miss, State, Pentny
Jackson, Miss
January 24th 1869

Honorable Thos Shackleford.
Canton, Miss.
Judge.

I was told by Lieut John. K. Haynes that you would upon your arrival at Canton, Miss, search the Records of the Inferior Court before whose tribunal I was duly committed to await the Action of the Circuit Court of Madison County, Now, Your Honor to save you the trouble of hunting different Courts, I have the honor to state here to you, that I was arrested on the 21st day of November 1867, by Marshall Hill and One Mr Wise who is I believe an Auctioneer in Canton, I was on that same day remanded to Prison by Justice Foote, and sometime near the latter part of same Month, I was brought before Justice Foote, and by him committed in default of Bail for the crime of Obtaining the sum of Twenty-two ($22 00/100) dollars from One Henry Lord of Canton, Miss, I afterwards on the 4th April 1868 plead Guilty to that Charge
over.
and was sentenced by Judge A. P. Campbell of the Circuit Court to the State Penitentiary.

Now, Judge I am a stranger to this part of the Country, I have no friends on the Outside to intercede for me, and no money to fee a Lawyer, you therefore perceive that I am indeed much to be pitied, and I therefore return you my sincere thanks for the kind interest you have taken in my behalf, I do not say that I am innocent of the crime for which I am imprisoned, No, far from it, I am guilty as far as the Act was concerned, but I assure You that the intention was good, and the Parties interested would never have lost a cent through me, I am a young man Judge, and this Country is vast and extensive, procure my release from this Prison, and I promise you that I will become an honest man for the future, and sin no more, and rest assure Judge that your kindness. towards me shall never be forgotten.
Hoping Judge that you will succeed in finding out the amount for which I stand charge with
I have the honor to subscribed myself over.
Your humble Servant.
Malcolm Moss.

P. S. Mr Saul Calhoun the District Attorney will probably recollect the Amount, I sincerely hope that he will have a better Memory than Mr Henry Lord who says that he does not know how much I stole from him, You must recollect Judge that he was the very man who offered me the Twenty-two $2200/100 dollars and afterwards had me arrested, but I hope that you will find the Amount upon Justice Foote's Record.
Your Obd't Servn't
M. Moss.
I respectfully recommend the pardon and release of the above prisoner M. Moss— [?]
S. S. Calhoun, dist. Atty. 5th Js.

Executive Office
Jackson Miss
January 26th1869.
Respectfully refered to Capt. Jasper Myers Atty Genl for his Opinion—

Atty Gens Office
Jackson Miss
Jan 27th 1869

Respectfully returned By the act approved Nov 24th 1865—entitled "An act to establish County Courts." the stealing of any sum less than one hundred dollars is made petit larceny and a mis-demeanor. and hence not punishable by imprison-ment in the penitentiary. In the present case the party is evidently illegal-ly detained. I would respect-fully recom-mend his pardon

Jasper Myers
Act Atty Gen of Miss
